data.title: 2.1 Display any factors that have a negative impact on your project
data.description: Identify, track, and publicly disclose negative external factors.

criteria.title: External factors
criteria.description: Identify existing or potential negative external factors affecting a project. Disclose these in a publicly available resource, identifying areas where digital sustainability can be improved. Perform this audit at the start of your project and at regular intervals.

data.title: 2.2 Understand user requirements or constraints, resolving barriers to access
data.description: Understand the audience and their requirements, remove their constraints and barriers, and give them an equal role in decision making.

criteria.title: Audience evaluation
criteria.description: Identify primary and secondary target users. Evaluate and define their needs through quantitative and/or qualitative research, testing, or analytics. Ensure your users and affected communities are consistently and closely involved in the research and testing process.

criteria.title: User constraints
criteria.description: Account for potential user constraints, such as the device age, operating system choice or version, browser, Virtual Private Network (VPN) use, and connection speeds when designing and assessing the quality of user experiences.

criteria.title: Barriers and access
criteria.description: Conduct internal and user research to identify whether a technical, material, or human constraint might require adaptations to reduce barriers or improve access to content.

criteria.title: Barrier removal
criteria.description: Remove identified barriers to access. These can include deceptive design patterns, accessibility issues, or other pain points.

criteria.title: Seat at the table
criteria.description: Assign all involved parties, including users, an equitable role in the decision-making process when undertaking research, identifying needs, or iterative design work.

data.title: 2.3 Understand the impact for non-users
data.description: Account for non-users who may be indirectly affected by the environmental impact of the project.

criteria.title: Non-user impact
criteria.description: Establish a plan of action for non-users and other affected parties who might be indirectly impacted by choices made in e-commerce, this can include neighbors accepting parcels or traffic jams due to deliveries. Other examples include the local health impacts of infrastructure emissions, or supply chain pressure. Research non-user needs, understand how they might be affected, and consider ways negative effects could be mitigated.

data.title: 2.4 Integrate sustainability into every stage of the ideation process
data.description: Optimize materials created at every stage of the process and involve users in the creation process.

criteria.title: Sustainable brand development
criteria.description: Optimize all branding materials and assets approved during the ideation process in line with sustainability best practices prior to deployment. This also applies to brand refreshes, rebranding, and later enhancements. Make publicly available branding guidelines detailing the sustainability impact and best-practice deployment of materials and assets.

criteria.title: Wireframes and prototypes
criteria.description: Use wireframes and rapid prototyping to quickly build consensus, reduce risk, and reduce the number of resources needed to build features. Evaluate the impact of all tools used.

criteria.title: Participation and testing
criteria.description: Use the participatory design approach to involve users within the iteration and design process. When conducting user testing, reach out to your community to help improve your product. Provide opportunities for users to apply their knowledge and experience to your product or service.

data.title: 2.5 Find ways to resolve any affected party issues prior to implementation
data.description: Consider the needs of and impact on users, the planet, and other affected parties.

criteria.title: Human-centered ideation
criteria.description: Use a human-centered approach during ideation to consider the needs, interests, and impact on directly and indirectly affected parties.

criteria.title: Environmental ideation
criteria.description: Consider planetary needs and environmental boundaries during the ideation phase. This can include creating non-user, non-human (animal, planet) personas, or climate-specific user stories and sprints.

data.title: 2.6 Minimize non-essential content, interactivity, or journeys
data.description: Use distraction and clutter-free design, showing the visitor only what they need without interruptions or wasted resource consumption.

criteria.title: Efficient paths
criteria.description: Make access as simple and efficient as possible. Displaying the time required to complete an action, reduction of choice, and ensuring users understand requirements at the start of a journey can improve user efficiency.

criteria.title: Patterns for efficiency
criteria.description: Ensure user journeys are as smooth as possible. It also helps to build on established design patterns that people already understand.

criteria.title: Distraction-free design
criteria.description: Enable users to complete tasks without distractions or non-essential features getting in the way.

criteria.title: Eliminate the non-essential
criteria.description: Only show users information that is relevant to their experience, hiding non-essential information from view.

criteria.title: User-initiated actionable content
criteria.description: Ensure that disruptive actionable information, such as pop-up or modal windows, can only be initiated by the user.

data.title: 2.7 Use decorative design with care
data.description: Use decorative design only when it will enhance experiences rather than distracting or detracting from an interface.

criteria.title: Decorative design
criteria.description: Use decorative design only when it enhances user experience. Remove unnecessary assets or those that do not enhance user experience or sustainability. Alternatively, make these optional and disabled by default.

data.title: 2.8 Ensure that navigation and wayfinding are well-structured
data.description: Provide good information architecture that signposts visitors to what they need, both human and machine, so they can reach their destination as efficiently as possible.

criteria.title: Navigation and search
criteria.description: Provide an accessible, easy-to-use navigation menu with search features to help users easily find what they need.

criteria.title: Human-readable sitemaps
criteria.description: Consider implementing an efficient and regularly updated sitemap for human users. While guidance beyond the navigation bar may be unnecessary for smaller projects, clearly structured human-readable sitemaps can improve accessibility and help users find their way through websites or other online content with naturally complex or legacy information architecture.

criteria.title: New content
criteria.description: Implement lightweight and efficient means for users to learn about new content and services.

data.title: 2.9 Design to assist and not to distract
data.description: Provide engagement that keeps the visitor's focus where it needs to be, avoiding anything that will either reduce efficiency or artificially prolong engagement.

criteria.title: User attention
criteria.description: Ensure users can easily control how and when they receive information, with respect for their attention, focus, and mental energy.

criteria.title: Distraction
criteria.description: Prioritize features that assist rather than distract users, not unnecessarily prolonging the time they spend engaging with your content.

criteria.title: Engagement traps
criteria.description: Avoid using design strategies intended to artificially prolong user attention, such as infinite scroll.

data.title: 2.10 Use established design patterns and appropriate components
data.description: Use established and recognizable patterns to increase the efficiency of the user journey.

criteria.title: Design patterns
criteria.description: Display only essential components at the time they are needed. Where appropriate, use familiar patterns to maximize ease of use.

data.title: 2.11 Avoid being manipulative or deceptive
data.description: Avoid using patterns, content, tools, or techniques that may artificially manipulate or deceive the visitor and waste energy.

criteria.title: Deceptive design patterns
criteria.description: Avoid deceptive design or unethical coding techniques that manipulate users into taking actions that are not in their best interest. Examples include anti-right click, copy prevention, requiring an account to purchase, etc.

criteria.title: Advertisements
criteria.description: Select, present, and label advertisements and sponsorships transparently and only implement where these provide economic and ethical value without diminishing user experience.

criteria.title: Analytics and tracking
criteria.description: Evaluate and remove unnecessary or unused analytics and tracking, including any operating without user consent.

criteria.title: Search Engine Optimization
criteria.description: Focus on serving user intent through non-manipulative search and social media optimization. For example, do not misuse coding practices intended to support assistive technologies. This can include content with natural redundancy, or unhelpful or low-quality material designed only to manipulate search results.

data.title: 2.12 Make deliverables understandable and reusable
data.description: Create well documented deliverables so that future users can find and make use of them without requiring assistance or expending unnecessary time and resources.

criteria.title: Deliverables Reusability
criteria.description: Create deliverables, including documentation, in ways that facilitate later reuse.

criteria.title: Deliverables Documentation
criteria.description: Document functionality and technical specifications so that they can be understood by everyone that needs to use them.

criteria.title: Deliverables Readability
criteria.description: Developers have access to code comments and have the ability to view source to make it easier to access, understand, maintain, and use code.

data.title: 2.13 Use a design system for interface consistency
data.description: Keep the components of the project as consistent and clear as possible by using a design system to organize reusable features.

criteria.title: Design system
criteria.description: Use a design system based on web standards and established patterns to share interface components and ensure a consistent user experience.

data.title: 2.14 Provide clear, inclusive content with purpose
data.description: Provide content that meets the needs of the audience, ensuring it is formatted for readability and incorporating SEO for visibility.

criteria.title: Clear content
criteria.description: Write content using plain and inclusive language, at an appropriate reading level for your audience. Account for specific needs in relation to accessibility, native language, and internationalization.

criteria.title: Content formatting
criteria.description: Use appropriate formatting for digital media. Provide a clear document structure with consideration of visual hierarchy. Use headings, bulleted lists, line spacing, and highlights appropriately. Provide information with appropriate formatting for the action users need to take.

criteria.title: Search Engine Optimization (SEO)
criteria.description: Prioritize SEO from the early design stages and throughout the lifecycle to ensure content can be found and used.

data.title: 2.15 Optimize images for sustainability
data.description: Ensure images, if required, are optimized, correctly formatted, and sized, with lazy loading as appropriate, and are managed effectively.

criteria.title: Need for images
criteria.description: Determine the need for images with consideration of the quantity, format, and sizes required.

criteria.title: Optimized images
criteria.description: Resize, optimize, and compress each image. Provide images in appropriate sizes for different screen resolutions.

criteria.title: Lazy loading
criteria.description: Include lazy loading to ensure images only load when they are required.

criteria.title: Sizing and deactivation
criteria.description: Provide the option for images to be disabled or provide a low-fidelity alternative.

criteria.title: Image management and use
criteria.description: Set up a media management and use policy to reduce the overall impact of images. Include criteria for media compression and file formats.

data.title: 2.16 Optimize media for sustainability
data.description: Ensure media, if required, are optimized, correctly formatted, and sized, with deferred loading as appropriate, and are managed effectively.

criteria.title: Need for media
criteria.description: Do not include any video or audio unless it provides positive value. Disable auto-play functionality on audio and video.

criteria.title: Optimized media
criteria.description: Optimize and compress media appropriately. Provide media in compatible and appropriate formats. Avoid non-native embedded media players.

criteria.title: Deferred loading
criteria.description: Load data-intensive media on the client side, including the media itself, behind a facade - a non-functional and static representational element.

criteria.title: Labels and choice
criteria.description: Let the user control media, including a choice of resolutions and formats and the option to deactivate media. Inform users the length, format, and data intensity of the media.

criteria.title: Management and usage
criteria.description: Establish media management and use policy to evaluate and reduce the overall impact of media, such as audio, video, or emerging media formats. Include criteria for media compression and file formats.

data.title: 2.17 Ensure animation is proportionate and easy to control
data.description: Ensure any animation deemed necessary is not overdone and that the user can control its ability to run.

criteria.title: Need for animation
criteria.description: Use animation only when it adds value and not for decorative elements.

criteria.title: Avoiding overburdening
criteria.description: Progressively display an appropriate number of animations to avoid overburdening the user or negatively impacting device performance. This includes setting a maximum number of replays or iterations.

criteria.title: Control animation
criteria.description: Allow users to start, stop, pause, or otherwise control animated content.

data.title: 2.18 Use optimized and appropriate web typography
data.description: Provide custom fonts in a highly optimized and correct format, but with a preference for pre-installed typefaces where possible.

criteria.title: Pre-installed typefaces
criteria.description: Use pre-installed, web-safe typefaces wherever possible.

criteria.title: Font optimization
criteria.description: Limit the number of fonts used. Design or subset fonts to omit unnecessary or unused variations, such as font weight or characters. Use the most performant file format available.

data.title: 2.19 Offer suitable alternatives for every format used
data.description: Integrate fallbacks so that if something cannot load or is not compatible, there is an accessible alternative to ensure equal access to the content.

criteria.title: Open formats
criteria.description: Provide open alternatives, such as HTML, to proprietary file formats, such as PDF.

criteria.title: Font stack fallbacks
criteria.description: Provide a suitable font stack as a fallback when custom typefaces are used.

criteria.title: Alternative text
criteria.description: Provide meaningful alternative text for all descriptive images that are non-decorative and support the user's understanding of the content.

criteria.title: Transcripts and text
criteria.description: Include transcripts and/or text versions of media files as an alternative to playing the media.

criteria.title: Video alternatives
criteria.description: Include WebVTT closed captions and subtitles support for videos. Provide localization as expected by your audience, including subtitles and sign language that meet the same standard.

data.title: 2.20 Provide accessible, user-friendly, minimal web forms
data.description: Ensure forms are as minimalistic and friction-free as possible, reducing the impact of submitting data.

criteria.title: Simple forms
criteria.description: Remove unnecessary forms and reduce form content to the minimum necessary to meet the user needs while satisfying the organization's minimum requirements. Clearly communicate why a form is necessary, the value it provides, the number of steps required for completion, and what will be done with the collected data. Also disclose if the data will be shared with third parties.

criteria.title: Functional forms
criteria.description: Avoid using auto-completion or auto-suggest based on partial entry to conserve user bandwidth and reduce unnecessary server side requests. Support the use of helpful tooling, such as password managers, by not preventing autofill.

data.title: 2.21 Consider the experience in non-visual browsers and interfaces
data.description: Ensure visitors who access your content using non-visual methods have an equal experience.

criteria.title: Alternative interactions
criteria.description: Support non-visual browsing methods and various non-graphical ways to interact with content. This includes anything from assistive technologies to voice agents. Consider and provide working alternatives to visual interfaces.

data.title: 2.22 Provide useful notifications
data.description: Ensure any required notifications or alerts are clearly explained before activation, and that the user can both control and change them.

criteria.title: Need for notification
criteria.description: Remove non-essential notifications. Justify and reduce email, text message (SMS), and other invasive or energy-intense notifications to what is strictly necessary. Useful notifications, such as alerts for new content should be used with care and restraint, having both the users understanding and informed consent.

criteria.title: Notification settings
criteria.description: Let the user adjust their own notification and messaging settings. Ensure the options to unsubscribe, log out, and close an account should be available and visible. Ensure it is possible for the user to change their contact details.

criteria.title: Prompts and responses
criteria.description: Clearly explain the result of a potential input through helpful prompts and messages that explain errors, next steps, and other relevant information. This will help to manage user's expectations.

data.title: 2.23 Reduce the impact of downloadable and physical documents
data.description: Reduce the need for physical documents as much as possible by allowing the saving of well-labeled, optimized digital downloads and having a print style sheet.

criteria.title: Printed documents
criteria.description: Design your process to reduce the need for paper documents. Where the production of paper documents is essential, it should be designed to have the lowest impact possible. Include a CSS print style sheet and test it with different types of content. Encourage saving documents in digital formats over paper-based storage and archiving.

criteria.title: Optimized documents
criteria.description: Optimize and compress all downloadable documents. Make them available in a variety of accessible file formats.

criteria.title: Optimized delivery
criteria.description: Avoid duplicating effort. If a document will be reused, generate and save it once on the server side for reuse, ideally on a cookie-free domain.

criteria.title: Labels and choice
criteria.description: Display the document name, a summary, the file size, and the format prior to downloading. Allow users to choose the right format and language for their needs where possible. Avoid embedding documents directly; provide a link to download or view them within the browser instead.

data.title: 2.24 Get users and contributors invested in the project
data.description: Document how you test new features with real users and validate the results, ensuring resources and training are provided to maintain the project's viability.

criteria.title: New features and perspectives
criteria.description: Outline processes used to prototype and test new features, product ideas, and user interface components. Test with real users who represent different perspectives and user constraints.

criteria.title: Resourcing and viability
criteria.description: Ensure prototyping and testing processes are sufficiently resourced to support long-term viability and avoid project abandonment.

criteria.title: Training and onboarding
criteria.description: Produce or provide, training materials to properly educate and onboard new contributors.

criteria.title: Testing and validation
criteria.description: Conduct regular and extensive testing alongside user interviews to validate whether released features meet internal goals and audience needs.

data.title: 2.25 Audit and test for bugs or issues requiring resolution
data.description: Regularly audit for issues or problems, running tests at regular intervals to ensure stability of the project.

criteria.title: Regular audit
criteria.description: Check the codebase for bugs, identify performance issues, and account for accessibility or security problems at appropriate regular intervals, such as every month or quarter.

criteria.title: Non-regression tests
criteria.description: Implement non-regression tests for all critical features.

criteria.title: Regression tests
criteria.description: Incorporate regression testing into each release cycle to ensure new features do not introduce bugs or otherwise conflict with existing functionality.

data.title: 2.26 Measure and test for performance
data.description: Check for performance issues in both simulated and real-world scenarios while also accounting for compliance issues.

criteria.title: Performance testing
criteria.description: Identify and resolve bottlenecks or issues in the underlying code or infrastructure which could impact sustainability and performance. Consider both simulated and real-world metrics. Monitor performance across every release cycle using appropriate tooling or through research and auditing.

criteria.title: Compliant measurement
criteria.description: Collect only data required to provide a streamlined and effective user journey and comply with relevant accessibility and data protection legislation. Put policies in place to ensure strict adherence.

data.title: 2.27 Evaluate feature use, value, and impact
data.description: Factor the ways people use the project into your decision making and consider how this can be optimized for both people and the planet.

criteria.title: Usage changes
criteria.description: Monitor user feedback, adoption, and churn rates in relation to different features and incorporate these insights into future releases.

data.title: 2.28 Verify that real-world users can successfully use your work
data.description: Run usability tests to determine if the impact of the project can be further iterated to reduce friction points.

criteria.title: Usability testing
criteria.description: Incorporate usability testing into product cycles and routinely measure the impact of these tests for future releases.

data.title: 2.29 Regularly test and maintain compatibility
data.description: Produce a regularly updated compatibility policy that details support levels, scenarios tested against, and technology used to benefit users.

criteria.title: Compatibility policy
criteria.description: Establish and maintain a compatibility policy which covers current and obsolete devices and software versions, listing the supported device brands, operating systems, and browsers (including versions). Update this regularly in line with new releases.

criteria.title: Maintaining compatibility
criteria.description: Avoid planned obsolescence. Strive to maintain compatibility for as long as possible and communicate clearly whether an update is evolutionary, as in large updates that can significantly reduce performance, or corrective, as in smaller updates that fix bugs or improve security.

criteria.title: Frequent testing
criteria.description: Test performance in various scenarios to ensure compatibility. Testing should cover weak, unstable, restricted, or slow connections, old browsers, and devices older than five years.

criteria.title: Mobile friendly
criteria.description: Use device-adaptable methods such as responsive design and prototype interfaces to support progressive enhancement and content prioritization.

criteria.title: Progressive Web Applications (PWAs)
criteria.description: Use a PWA over a native mobile application if it meets sustainability, interoperability, and compatibility criteria.

data.title: 3.1 Set goals based on performance and energy impact
data.description: Account for the difference in energy intensity that different types of content may have on a project and set goals based on what you would like to achieve.

criteria.title: Performance goals
criteria.description: Set clear goals with performance and environmental impact in mind, then meet them. These could include, the number of requests or elements that must be rendered.

criteria.title: Energy intensity
criteria.description: Consider differences in the energy intensity or testable impact across each component. For example, unstyled text is less computationally intensive to render than CSS, which in turn is less process-heavy than JavaScript, which is less resource-heavy than WebGL or 4K video.

data.title: 3.2 Remove unnecessary or redundant information
data.description: Remove redundant characters from code to reduce the amount of data being stored and transferred to devices.

criteria.title: Minified code
criteria.description: Remove unnecessary white space, comments, and other non-essential characters from code and data files to reduce file sizes and improve loading times. This applies to HTML, CSS, JavaScript, JSON, SVG, and other relevant file types.

data.title: 3.3 Modularize bandwidth-heavy components
data.description: Break down large components into smaller, self-contained pieces that can be requested only when required to save bandwidth.

criteria.title: Code splitting
criteria.description: Break down bandwidth-heavy components into smaller, modular segments that can be loaded only when required. This applies to both front-end and back-end code.

data.title: 3.4 Remove unnecessary code
data.description: Clear out dead or unused code as it builds up in a project to reduce the amount of wasted data being transferred.

criteria.title: Remove redundancy
criteria.description: Identify and eliminate unused and dead code, commonly within CSS and JavaScript.

data.title: 3.5 Avoid redundancy and duplication in code
data.description: Improve solutions rather than recreating them, using good organization strategies to simplify code where possible and reduce redundancy.

criteria.title: Remove or simplify
criteria.description: Remove duplication and/or simplify and optimize your code for better performance, focusing on essential features so you have a cleaner, less redundant product and codebase.

criteria.title: Iteration over recreation
criteria.description: Improve existing solutions rather than redeveloping and redesigning products from scratch, since the latter would duplicate the coding effort and maintenance burden for developers rather than reduce the learning burden for users.

criteria.title: Organize code arrangement
criteria.description: Use organization methodology and systems such as Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY) or Write Everything Twice (WET) to optimize the arrangement and output of your JavaScript and CSS.

data.title: 3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment
data.description: Avoid using large third-party libraries and frameworks where possible, and where these must be used, self host, defer loading, allow the user to object, and provide alternatives.

criteria.title: Assess and reduce
criteria.description: Assess third-party content and/or services (including plugins, widgets, feeds, maps, carousels, tracking scripts, and more) as early as possible in the ideation or creation process. Use as few as possible, preferring lighter, less complex solutions to reduce the overall environmental impact, including Scope 3 emissions.

criteria.title: Third-party implementation
criteria.description: Use click-to-load triggers based on an import on interaction pattern to prevent automatic loading of third-party content and/or services (see above). Offer suitable alternatives to third-party use, for example, a link to a contact form as an alternative to a chat widget.

criteria.title: Libraries and frameworks
criteria.description: Avoid using large libraries and frameworks. Integrate these only when unable to use a more performant alternative to achieve the same goal.

criteria.title: Self-hosting
criteria.description: Prioritize self-hosted content over embedding content from third-party services.

criteria.title: Avoid dependencies
criteria.description: Host icons and widgets on your own server, rather than relying on third-party services to host and deliver these or embed third-party functionality within your project.

criteria.title: Third-party preferences
criteria.description: Respect user preferences around the use of third-party products and services, similar to the implementation of cookie consent modals. Provide mechanisms to disable or refuse non-first-party features alongside explanations of their purpose unless it is possible to show these third-party features are critical for functionality.

data.title: 3.7 Ensure code follows good semantic practices
data.description: Use semantic markup free of optional or non-standard code, only using custom solutions when native ones are insufficient.

criteria.title: Semantic code
criteria.description: Use accurate markup according to the relevant standard(s).

criteria.title: Optional features
criteria.description: Remove optional HTML elements, attribute quotes, and default attributes when these do not negatively impact functionality, accessibility, or readability. Retain them when they enhance accessibility, maintain clarity without compromising on performance, or ensure consistent browser rendering.

criteria.title: Avoid non-standard code
criteria.description: Avoid using non-standard HTML elements or attributes.

criteria.title: Custom code
criteria.description: Prioritize the use of standard HTML elements and attributes. Only use custom elements or Web Components if you cannot use native elements or if you require them for the purposes of producing reusable design system components.

data.title: 3.8 Defer the loading of non-critical resources
data.description: Avoid render-blocking slowdowns by asynchronously loading, deferring, or prioritizing external resources as appropriate.

criteria.title: Asynchronous code
criteria.description: Defer loading of non-essential external assets or set these to load asynchronously to avoid a Flash Of Unstyled Content (FOUC).

criteria.title: Optimized loading
criteria.description: Where external resources are required to be used upon the documents load, optimize loading using resource and priority hints.

data.title: 3.9 Provide information to help understand the usefulness of a page
data.description: Ensure that search engines, as well as accessibility tooling, can access a project to reduce wasted journeys.

criteria.title: Metadata and microdata
criteria.description: Optimize and only include suitable metadata and microdata.

criteria.title: Search engines
criteria.description: Permit appropriate access to search engines while blocking unsustainable robots and scripts.

criteria.title: Accessibility aids
criteria.description: Provide accessibility and usability aids, such as skip links and signposts, to help users find and navigate content.

data.title: 3.10 Validate form errors and account for tooling requirements
data.description: Label forms correctly while also checking for errors both prior to and during submission to reduce the impact of erroneous data entry.

criteria.title: Error validation
criteria.description: Identify errors through live validation and with feedback on submission.

criteria.title: Label elements
criteria.description: Clearly label and identify required elements to ensure easy recognition for users using assistive technologies.

criteria.title: Allow clipboard
criteria.description: Always allow the copying and pasting of content (including passwords) from external sources.

data.title: 3.11 Structure metadata for machine readability
data.description: Include the required metadata and structured microdata to increase the visibility and findability of resources.

criteria.title: Required elements
criteria.description: Include the required title element, plus any beneficial optional HTML head elements.

criteria.title: Meta tags
criteria.description: Include necessary meta tag references that are commonly recognized and used by user agents such as search engines. Follow recognized standards and vocabularies such as Friend of a Friend (FOAF) or RDFa.

criteria.title: Structured data
criteria.description: Use microdata, structured data (e.g., Schema.org), or microformats in content where a widely used structured data format exists.

data.title: 3.12 Use sustainability beneficial user preference media queries
data.description: Use sustainable media queries, such as dark mode and scripting media queries, to customize an interface to suit user preferences and reduce emissions.

criteria.title: Media and preference queries
criteria.description: Accommodate common user preferences, such as prefers-color-scheme, with corresponding CSS media queries. Consider accounting for additional user preferences, including monochrome, prefers-contrast, prefers-reduced-data, prefers-reduced-transparency, and prefers-reduced-motion preference queries where these will benefit your users. Use print and scripting media queries when they can improve sustainability.

data.title: 3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements
data.description: Use a mix of carbon-aware design techniques to adapt to different layouts, different modes of interaction, and also progressively enhance content.

criteria.title: Device-adaptable
criteria.description: Allow your project to work and adapt seamlessly across a variety of devices and screen sizes, including smartphones, tablets, laptops, desktop computers, smart TVs, and other emerging platforms. This ensures that content and functionality can be easily accessed and are suitably optimized for display on both smaller mobile devices and larger displays without limiting accessibility, usability, or design features on any specific device type. Implement robust fallback strategies to ensure that the digital product or service will not fail if it encounters unsupported technologies.

criteria.title: Progressive enhancement
criteria.description: Use progressive enhancement to enhance overall sustainability. This can involve a single approach or a careful combination, such as adaptive design, mobile-first design, or dynamic serving.

criteria.title: Carbon-aware design
criteria.description: Use carbon-aware design techniques to maximize your use of carbon-free energy. This is achieved by adapting the delivery of your project to current electricity availability and user grid load. This should include using situational design to reduce the codebase and disable non-essential functionality during high-intensity periods. Similarly, it should be possible to adapt the user interface to perform better with reduced hardware resources, where this measure can be taken to avoid scaling hardware resources and the resultant increase in emissions. It can also include designing algorithms that can automatically disable features based on set thresholds.

criteria.title: Alternative browsing
criteria.description: Support additional indirect methods of interaction, such as voice (speech), code (QR, etc.), reader view (browser, application, or RSS), or connected technologies (watch, appliance, transport, etc.).

data.title: 3.14 Use Standards-based JavaScript and APIs
data.description: Use JavaScript in an energy-efficient and accessible way, only using APIs and making external calls when this enhances a project's sustainability.

criteria.title: Sustainable JavaScript
criteria.description: Improve sustainability through accessible and performant code.

criteria.title: Sustainable APIs
criteria.description: Integrate energy-relevant APIs - such as Battery Status, Compression Streams, Page Visibility, or Vibration - where these can reduce energy consumption.

criteria.title: API requests
criteria.description: Call client- or server-side APIs only when necessary. Equally, ensure an API is optimized to only send data that is actually required.

data.title: 3.15 Ensure that your code is secure
data.description: Regularly check code for exploitable security issues that could affect both users and hosting infrastructure.

criteria.title: Code security
criteria.description: Check scripts and associated code for vulnerabilities, exploits, header issues, and code injection.

data.title: 3.16 Use dependencies appropriately and ensure maintenance
data.description: Use libraries and frameworks only where necessary, when vanilla code or smaller packages are inappropriate for the use case, and they are kept up to date.

criteria.title: Dependency management
criteria.description: Prevent developers from downloading and installing libraries and frameworks to run client-side when they are not needed by checking for unused dependencies. Follow up by uninstalling those that are not needed.

criteria.title: Dependency necessity
criteria.description: Limit your use of libraries and frameworks to the genuinely necessary as this will reduce the amount of code that has to be downloaded and parsed by the browser. Consider whether you can use vanilla code instead. Check the package size and whether individual modules can be installed and imported individually, as opposed to the entire library.

criteria.title: Dependency updates
criteria.description: Regularly check dependencies and keep them up to date.

data.title: 3.17 Include expected and beneficial files
data.description: Always provide expected files and optionally offer environmentally or otherwise beneficial files to enhance the project.

criteria.title: Expected files
criteria.description: Include favicon.ico, robots.txt, opensearch.xml, site.webmanifest, and sitemap.xml files by default. Also ensure that any similar files defined in future web standards or specifications are included.

criteria.title: Beneficial files
criteria.description: Include beneficial files such as ads.txt, carbon.txt, humans.txt, security.txt. Also ensure that any similar files defined in future web standards or specifications are included.

data.title: 3.18 Avoid using deprecated, proprietary, or outdated code
data.description: Stick to the latest version of language specifications when coding unless you have a documented need to do otherwise.

criteria.title: Preferred code
criteria.description: Avoid using deprecated, proprietary, or outdated formats and web standards. Always adopt up-to-date, widely recognized standards. Only use deprecated, proprietary, or outdated code where this is required to meet a documented customer need and if there is a justifiable benefit that cannot otherwise be met. Justifiable reasons could include compatibility with essential legacy systems and/or hardware, accessibility, or emissions reduction. Use polyfills only when necessary, and regularly audit code to see if they can be removed

data.title: 3.19 Use the most efficient solution for your service
data.description: Identify the project requirements, use the most efficient approach, aim for static over dynamic where possible, and consider the impact of extensions and components.

criteria.title: Identify requirements
criteria.description: Identify the requirements and use this as a basis to help you select the most appropriate implementation for your project. A simpler technological implementation may use more human resources but could have a smaller footprint. A prebuilt solution may use more system resources and have a bigger emissions impact on render, but it could have a faster build time - meaning less carbon is emitted in development.

criteria.title: Optimized methodology
criteria.description: Use the most effective approach for your use case. Most of the time, coding from scratch will often provide the most performant results. Where an existing solution is present and is being actively maintained, this may be better optimized than what you can reasonably produce yourself. Favor native components and file systems over WYSIWYG editors - including visual page builders - or other heavy frameworks. Be mindful of the impact of third-party solutions.

criteria.title: Static over dynamic
criteria.description: Deliver static in place of dynamic content wherever possible. If you choose to use a code generation tool, then favor the most efficient tool available, such as Static Site Generators (SSGs). Content delivered by a dynamic CMS will involve much more server-side processing and uses bulkier libraries.

criteria.title: Extensions and plugins
criteria.description: Carefully select and review plugins, extensions, and themes to maximize interoperability, accessibility, and performance. Audit these regularly over time to ensure continued compatibility.

criteria.title: Interface components
criteria.description: Pay particular attention to user interface components with respect to their sustainability impact.

data.title: 3.20 Use the latest stable language version
data.description: Consider the environmental impact of the chosen syntax language, while always ensuring you use the latest build of any language or framework.

criteria.title: Versioning
criteria.description: Use the latest build of your chosen syntax language and its coupled framework.

criteria.title: Language choice
criteria.description: Use the most appropriate programming language for the task. Many tools and programming languages are optimized for the performance of particular tasks. Applying the most appropriate tools to the problem can justify any time or effort involved in their adoption, especially if there is a reasonable user base, provided it does not impact the wellbeing of those involved or risk becoming cost-prohibitive.

data.title: 3.21 Take advantage of native features and functionality
data.description: Use native features and functionality that exist within languages before constructing new ones that may not be as optimized.

criteria.title: Native over custom
criteria.description: Use native functions, APIs, and features over writing your own.

data.title: 3.22 Reduce the number and complexity of database queries
data.description: Optimize any information provided via databases, both in terms of access schedules and how queries are sent and received.

criteria.title: Database queries
criteria.description: Optimize database queries, especially for frequently accessed information. If you need information that is stored in a database, and you require it or it is likely to be requested more than once in your code, the database should only be accessed once and the data stored locally for subsequent processing. Avoid relying on framework helpers that might defer filtering to later in the process.

data.title: 4.1 Choose a sustainable service provider
data.description: Ensure hosting and domain service providers support monitoring of resource use, use carbon-free electricity, and maintain and recycle equipment properly.

criteria.title: Monitor Metrics
criteria.description: Monitor key indicators to assess and transparently report the environmental impact of hosting and identify overconsumption. These include energy and water usage, but also hardware factors, such as CPU usage and memory usage. Similarly, track the allocation of servers and CPU cores to optimize resource efficiency. Consumers should monitor and providers should both calculate and transparently share, environmental impact metrics. Metrics should include Power Usage Effectiveness (PUE), Water Usage Effectiveness (WUE), and Carbon Usage Effectiveness (CUE).

criteria.title: Equipment longevity
criteria.description: Maintain hardware to extend its lifespan as long as possible. Use it efficiently at an appropriate capacity, and ensuring it has the necessary certifications. New purchases should be from reliable long-lifespan suppliers.

criteria.title: E-waste management
criteria.description: Responsibly recycle or upcycle unwanted waste. Materials should be recovered and reused, where possible, or otherwise disposed of appropriately.

criteria.title: Carbon-free electricity
criteria.description: Use electricity with the lowest possible carbon intensity. Examine location-based emissions factors to calculate the carbon intensity of available electricity from the regional grid. Include the impact of on-site electricity generation, including backup generators, in calculations.

criteria.title: Remaining emissions
criteria.description: Balance unavoidable remaining carbon emissions with high-quality market based instruments or other evolving instruments from the voluntary carbon market, until additional carbon-free energy resources become available. The quality of market-based instruments should be verified by non-profit third-party organizations with sufficient supporting evidence.

criteria.title: Domain names
criteria.description: The impact of domain names is disclosed by registries and registrars, and registrants consider and (where possible) mitigate against these environmental issues.

data.title: 4.2 Optimize caching with offline access supported
data.description: Use caching on all appropriate resources, prioritizing the ability to use the resource offline if possible.

criteria.title: Utilize caching
criteria.description: Use server-side caching where possible to reduce processing time and repeated database lookups or API calls. Configure caching via server settings to control file-type expiration using appropriate headers, such as Expires or Cache-Control. Cache dynamic page responses where possible to serve static versions to future users. Support client-side caching of frequently used static assets to minimize repeat server requests.

criteria.title: Offline access
criteria.description: Ensure resources remain available and accessible even if the user is disconnected, using methods such as JavaScript Service Workers, Web Workers, and browser local storage features.

data.title: 4.3 Compress files where it is beneficial
data.description: Use compression on all appropriate resources either before or as part of the transfer process.

criteria.title: Server-side compression
criteria.description: Use server-side compression to reduce file sizes before delivery. Server-side compression settings and tools can be used to compress most commonly used file types, reducing energy consumption while minimizing load times, saving bandwidth, and improving overall performance.

criteria.title: Media compression
criteria.description: Use media compression tools to reduce the file size of images, videos, audio, and any other media before uploading to a server.

data.title: 4.4 Setup necessary error pages and redirection links
data.description: Use error and redirection handling on projects to reduce the impact of wasted journeys or unhelpful detours.

criteria.title: Error pages
criteria.description: Set up proper error handling and error pages to clearly inform users when something goes wrong, guide them back to useful content, and maintain a consistent, trustworthy experience.

criteria.title: redirection
criteria.description: Regularly audit to check for broken and outdated links. Update these as necessary and add redirects to guide users and search engines to the correct content to ensure efficient browsing and protect SEO value. Test all redirects to ensure they function as intended and avoid impactful redirect loops. Favor the most efficient redirection system for your setup (e.g., server rules over database lookups).

data.title: 4.5 Avoid maintaining unnecessary virtualized environments or containers
data.description: Reduce the number of unnecessary virtualized environments to save hardware utilization.

criteria.title: Unused environments
criteria.description: Minimize the number of active environments, including virtualized environments (such as containers). Audit codebases for unused branches and environments and remove them as appropriate.

data.title: 4.6 Use automation wisely
data.description: Automate recurring tasks only where this saves resources, such as scaling services to reduce consumption or handling suspicious activity.

criteria.title: Automate tasks
criteria.description: Automate recurring tasks, such as deployment, testing, and compilation in alignment with continuous integration and continuous delivery best practices.

criteria.title: Qualify tasks
criteria.description: Run automated tasks only when necessary to reduce unnecessary resource utilisation.

criteria.title: Automated scaling
criteria.description: Use automated scaling to promptly adjust server capacity up or down based on demand, ensuring efficient resource allocation. Implement buffering and throttling to manage load and maintain performance without overprovisioning.

criteria.title: Suspicious activity filtering
criteria.description: Restrict the activity of unwanted and unnecessary third-party crawlers, suspicious user agents, unwanted users, bots, and scrapers from accessing or downloading your content. Follow best practices, such as server access rules and security tools, while ensuring your content remains accessible to users, search engines and any helpful, welcome crawlers. Consider that scrapers may be used to inform and train large language models.

data.title: 4.7 Define the frequency of data refreshes
data.description: Decide when to refresh data based on a balance of user and sustainability considerations.

criteria.title: Refresh frequency
criteria.description: Define the revalidation and refresh frequency for the cache, local data, and page content based on user needs, balancing performance, data accuracy, and resource efficiency.

data.title: 4.8 Back up critical data at routine intervals
data.description: Back up data at regular intervals to ensure that there are failsafes that can be relied upon should an issue occur.

criteria.title: Data backups
criteria.description: Ensure backups of system and user data are secure and incremental to minimize storage use, reduce backup time, and protect against data loss or breaches.

data.title: 4.9 Consider the impact and requirements of data processing
data.description: Account for the energy involved in data transfer, considering factors such as the protocol used, whether it is processed client- or server-side, and the environment used.

criteria.title: Batch processing
criteria.description: Use existing and supported carbon-aware computing methods to automate batching and scheduling according to real-time electrical grid carbon intensity data or shift workloads to lower-carbon regions to optimize sustainability while maintaining performance.

criteria.title: Protocols
criteria.description: Choose communication protocols appropriate to user needs and the type of data being transferred. Avoid insecure options such as HTTP and FTP, and prioritize secure, efficient alternatives such as HTTPS and SSH. Use modern protocols to take advantage of newer features, while maintaining backward compatibility for older devices.

criteria.title: Event-driven architecture
criteria.description: Consider using event-driven architecture and microservices when building products with state changes that do not require full page refreshes. Favor these where they offer a more energy-efficient alternative to traditional APIs based on performance, power, and processing factors. Choose the approach that reduces server workload and environmental impact.

criteria.title: Client vs server
criteria.description: Avoid redundant processing. When data processing is necessary, carefully compare the relative effects of client- versus server-side processing based on efficiency, performance, security, and sustainability metrics to make an informed decision.

data.title: 4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately
data.description: Use CDNs where they bring a sustainability benefit, ensuring the provider itself is sustainable, has nodes local to an audience, and they are only used to serve static resources on them.

criteria.title: Global CDNs
criteria.description: Deploy static content, assets, and other read-only resources via a Content Delivery Network (CDN) on a case-by-case basis, where judged to be beneficial. Carefully evaluate the environmental impact of any CDN service used, similar to a web hosting provider.

criteria.title: Sustainability commitment
criteria.description: Select CDN providers that make commitments to sustainability and report on their progress.

criteria.title: Local servers
criteria.description: When serving an exclusively local audience, consider whether a CDN is required at all. Instead, select hosting providers with servers close to your target audience.

criteria.title: Inappropriate resources
criteria.description: Avoid deploying dynamic or frequently changing resources to a CDN. Browser behaviors such as cache partitioning and cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) can limit performance gains, hinder caching and interaction, and attempting to override these can introduce security or privacy risks. This does not apply to static assets or JSON files, which are well suited to CDN delivery.

criteria.title: Close to the source
criteria.description: Perform data transformations, transfers, and processing between the layers of an application as close to the source as possible. This reduces unnecessary serialization overhead and avoids wasting resources.

data.title: 4.11 Ensure infrastructure fits project requirements
data.description: Maintain the infrastructure you require rather than over-provisioning and autoscale to meet demand instead to preserve hardware resources.

criteria.title: Lowest requirements
criteria.description: Select infrastructure that meets your requirements and customer agreements without over-provisioning. Favor standalone instances over multi-zone or distributed setups when requirements allow. Provision for average loads rather than peaks to ensure efficient resource use. Use autoscaling to handle fluctuations without underutilizing infrastructure.

data.title: 4.12 Store data according to the needs of your users
data.description: Set expiration dates on data so it can be archived, made available offline, or removed when no longer used or required, with the remaining content tagged for future management.

criteria.title: Reduce redundancy
criteria.description: Regularly audit for and delete redundant, abandoned, or single-use data - often referred to as dark data - to reduce storage demand and energy use.

criteria.title: Expiration dates
criteria.description: Assign expiration and/or maximum retention dates to stored data where appropriate, treating excess data as a form of technical debt. Simultaneously observe any applicable minimum data retention periods. Make data cleanup an established organization-wide routine to prevent long-term data accumulation.

criteria.title: Classify and tag
criteria.description: Implement a data classification and tagging policy to improve visibility, simplify management, and enable efficient removal of outdated or unused data.

criteria.title: Justify storage
criteria.description: Store data only when it cannot be easily or accurately regenerated.

criteria.title: Optimize logging
criteria.description: Optimize log collection and storage by scheduling backups during low-activity hours, rotating logs appropriately, and using off-site, sustainable providers.

criteria.title: Asset downloads
criteria.description: Make large, long-term assets available for easy download in order to provide users with regular offline access without requiring persistant server resources.

data.title: 5.1 Have an ethical and sustainable product strategy
data.description: Produce policies and documents showcasing evidence, achievements, and onboarding underpinned by good governance.

criteria.title: Public documents
criteria.description: Develop, publish and maintain key policies, such as a code of ethics, product guidelines, sustainability statements, and/or other documents that include language specific to digital products, services, policies, and programs. Make these publicly accessible and transparently versioned formats.

criteria.title: Achievements and compliance
criteria.description: Publish achievements, features, compliance, and anything beyond the scope of these guidelines within a dedicated sustainability section.

criteria.title: Governance over time
criteria.description: Provide evidence to demonstrate how digital sustainability policies, climate policies, and related practices are effectively implemented, monitored, and governed over time.

criteria.title: Onboarding new members
criteria.description: Provide training decks and workshops to support onboarding new team members in relation to sustainable product strategies.

criteria.title: Documentation
criteria.description: Document your methodology through impact storytelling, documentation, and creating resources to help individuals make more informed decisions and raise awareness among your users.

criteria.title: Carbon-free evidence
criteria.description: Demonstrate how digital products and services are powered using carbon-free energy.

data.title: 5.2 Assign a sustainability advocate
data.description: Appoint a sustainability advocate who is provided with what they require to speak about and for issues relating to sustainability.

criteria.title: Advocate for sustainability
criteria.description: Assign a sustainability advocate with specific digital expertise and provide them with the resources, budget, tools, and time they need to achieve their stated goals. In some organizations, expanding this into a climate working group comprising motivated individuals can add further benefits.

data.title: 5.3 Inform, raise awareness, and train for sustainability
data.description: Drive sustainability awareness both externally and internally with active encouragement and routine training offered where necessary.

criteria.title: Inform and aware
criteria.description: Inform and deliver training to all affected parties, including product teams, colleagues, and organizational decision-makers - both managers and clients - in both general and digital climate literacy, as well as your own sustainable technology policies.

criteria.title: Routine training
criteria.description: Provide active and routine training where possible to develop, establish, and refresh skills relating to sustainability. This can be delivered as in-house training, courses, workshops, events, webinars, meetups, or other ongoing or on-demand methods that support your team in achieving sustainability objectives.

criteria.title: Active participation
criteria.description: Encourage participants to reduce their environmental impact. Share climate and sustainable initiatives and ideas. Provide resources on sustainable design, best practices, and concepts to assist them.

data.title: 5.4 Communicate the environmental impact of user choices
data.description: Empower visitors, allowing them to make decisions when their choices can influence the environmental impact they have.

criteria.title: Communication of impact
criteria.description: Clearly communicate the environmental impact of different user choices and allow users to configure settings based on the information provided.

data.title: 5.5 Estimate the environmental impact
data.description: Calculate the environmental impact of the project and any tooling you use, and even that of a competitor, where possible, as this may be useful for comparison.

criteria.title: Life-cycle analysis
criteria.description: Conduct a full life-cycle analysis based on the functional unit defined under guideline 5.15.

criteria.title: Competitor impact
criteria.description: Calculate the environmental impact of your or a competitor's current service to inform decision-making targets.

criteria.title: Tooling impact
criteria.description: Include the impact or estimated impact of any tooling or third-party solutions used at any stage in your pipeline. While not created by you, the emissions generated in production, maintenance, and use are also integral to your overall solution.

data.title: 5.6 Define clear organizational sustainability goals and metrics
data.description: Publish a set of sustainability goals that can be used to track progress over a period of time.

criteria.title: Sustainability goals
criteria.description: Define and publish a clear set of sustainability goals. Publicly communicate how these goals can be met, including which performance metrics can be measured to help the organization and its various affected parties act more sustainably.

data.title: 5.7 Validate efforts using established third-party certifications
data.description: Obtain and maintain third-party certifications to externally validate progress toward sustainability goals.

criteria.title: Obtaining certifications
criteria.description: Obtain one or more sustainability certifications and incorporate operational policies and practices in alignment with their guidance.

criteria.title: Maintaining certifications
criteria.description: Maintains sustainability certifications through continuing to meet their criteria and evolving policies and practices over time.

data.title: 5.8 Implement sustainability onboarding guidelines
data.description: Provide training materials and incentives to encourage participation from members of the organisation toward meeting sustainability goals.

criteria.title: Training materials
criteria.description: Create and/or deliver dedicated training manuals, workshops, and materials to outline the sustainability policies and practices adopted and how to implement them. Manage and maintain these materials over time, adapting them as new policies and best practices arise.

criteria.title: Incentivize progress
criteria.description: Incentivize leadership, teams, and individuals to make progress toward the goals outlined in their training. Examples include dedicating time for sustainability-related activities, recognizing completion, and other benefits.

criteria.title: Negative factors
criteria.description: Anticipate and map potential negative external factors and act to minimize their overall impact.

data.title: 5.9 Support mandatory disclosures and reporting
data.description: Create policies and documents showing evidence of commitment towards impact progress, how this is achieved, and any applicable regulations you are meeting.

criteria.title: Policies and practices
criteria.description: Create and publish policies and practices to disclose the social and environmental impacts of its products, programs, and services in line with existing reporting standards such as GRI, SASB, etc.

criteria.title: Impact reports
criteria.description: Produce a publicly available impact report outlining progress compared to previous reports on social and environmental goals at least once per year.

criteria.title: Standards and policies
criteria.description: Publicly and transparently demonstrate commitment over time to following and adopting existing and/or emerging environmental standards and legislative policy that promotes mandatory emissions disclosures and reporting.

criteria.title: Impact reduction
criteria.description: Clearly identify how environmental impact is being reduced, with careful avoidance of double accounting, greenwashing, data exclusion, or other misleading or manipulative techniques.

data.title: 5.10 Create one or more impact business models
data.description: Produce a document that shows how the organisation is taking steps to become as resilient as possible.

criteria.title: Theory of change
criteria.description: Complete and operationalize a theory of change process with requisite documentation to identify the impact the organization aspires to achieve, how it will generate revenue, how it will create shared or added value from these activities, and how it will measure results based on desired outcomes. In the case of projects already underway, how these are generating revenue and actively tracking and measuring progress against desired outcomes.

data.title: 5.11 Follow a product management and maintenance strategy
data.description: Explain through documentation how projects will be maintained, managed, resourced, and note issues while tracking measurements over time.

criteria.title: Management and maintenance
criteria.description: Produce and maintain documentation to outline how the organization approaches product management and maintenance.

criteria.title: Planning strategy
criteria.description: Establish maintenance and security plans for all digital products and services.

criteria.title: Resourcing products
criteria.description: Appropriately resource products over time via staffing and budgeting to support code refactoring, address technical debt, introduce new product features, test functionality, and produce product or service maintenance plans to continue supporting customers, users, and other affected parties.

criteria.title: Resource measurement
criteria.description: Incorporate carbon and resource measurement into maintenance programs and show measurable improvement over time.

criteria.title: Failure indicators
criteria.description: Identify and document Key Failure Indicators (KFIs) and implement resolutions to prevent negative sustainability impacts.

data.title: 5.12 Implement continuous improvement procedures
data.description: Continuously improve projects through regular reviews and iteration, integrating technical debt and security management, determining if new or existing functionality is required.

criteria.title: Continuous improvement
criteria.description: Establish policies and practices to enable continuous improvement and resource practices appropriately to support these efforts over time.

criteria.title: Retrospectives conducted
criteria.description: Review deliverables and update frequency to ensure project teams have enough time to conduct user research, identify technical debt, and produce high-quality output as well as share what they learned.

criteria.title: Iterative consideration
criteria.description: Display a track record of continuous improvement (iteration) processes to analyze the digital product or service. Simultaneously address any potential consequences of ongoing experimentation, such as technical debt, product performance, and emissions. Analytics are limited to strictly necessary features that aid decision-making, encouraging user feedback, and comparing performance against business goals and user needs.

criteria.title: Functionality decisions
criteria.description: Justify and prioritize the retention of existing features, the creation of new functionality, and the decommissioning or elimination of unused functionality or low-traffic content throughout the product's life cycle on a case-by-case basis.

criteria.title: Security updates
criteria.description: Provide corrective security and policy updates during the product or service life cycle. These should be distinguished from more extensive evolutionary updates.

criteria.title: Skills and maintenance
criteria.description: Develop sustainable product and data strategies using appropriate training techniques. These should help your team build capacity and learn new skills to manage and maintain products and services over time.

data.title: 5.13 Document future updates and evolutions
data.description: Provide documentation to help users find their way whenever functionality changes.

criteria.title: Feature changes
criteria.description: When a feature is added, updated, or removed to improve user experience, clear documentation of the changes is provided in a well structured, semantically versioned document.

data.title: 5.14 Establish if a digital product or service is necessary
data.description: Determine whether a project is necessary, avoiding duplication of existing efforts, creating obstacles for users, and aligning with SDGs and sustainability principles.

criteria.title: Sustainable Development Goals
criteria.description: Identify where the product or service aligns with one of the UN (SDGs) and its appropriate targets within a sustainability statement.

criteria.title: Creation evaluation
criteria.description: Determine that the product or service is necessary based upon desirability, feasibility, and viability factors.

criteria.title: Avoid duplication
criteria.description: Establish that no existing digital product or service offers the same value. Conduct an analysis to understand the market for this requirement.

criteria.title: Obstacle consideration
criteria.description: Remove or alleviate any obstacles to using a product or service, such as accessibility, equality, technical, or territorial.

data.title: 5.15 Conduct a full life-cycle assessment
data.description: Identify the potential impact that a digital product or service will have throughout its lifetime by conducting an LCA.

criteria.title: Life-cycle assessment
criteria.description: Conduct a Life-cycle assessment (LCA) to define sustainability-related functional impacts throughout a product's lifetime.

data.title: 5.16 Provide a supplier standards of practice document
data.description: Vet suppliers before onboarding, then collaborate to promote and encourage better sustainability practices.

criteria.title: Vetting potential partners
criteria.description: Create specific policies to vet potential partners along the supply chain based on sustainability principles.

criteria.title: Collaborative measurement
criteria.description: Partner with suppliers to create, track and measure impact on issues that impact affected parties.

criteria.title: Informative partner promotion
criteria.description: Promote and disclose partnerships in a publicly available place, along with information on how the partnership creates a collective impact.

data.title: 5.17 Share economic benefits
data.description: Share benefits associated with being sustainably resilient with workers, incentivizing efforts, and advocating for those involved to meet sustainability goals.

criteria.title: Living wage
criteria.description: Publicly commit to paying employees, contractors, and other affected parties a living wage.

criteria.title: Incentivisation
criteria.description: Have policies and practices to incentivize affected parties, such as workers and contractors, to meet impact goals.

criteria.title: Employee benefits
criteria.description: Provide benefits to employees in accordance with resources, including, where relevant, healthcare, retirement planning, flex time, profit sharing, and more.

criteria.title: Legislation advocacy
criteria.description: Advocate for responsible legislation that supports employment rights, transparency, and accountability related to sharing economic benefits.

data.title: 5.18 Share decision-making power with affected parties
data.description: Ensure that all affected parties have the opportunity to get involved in helping the organisation become more sustainable.

criteria.title: Decision-making
criteria.description: Align the project team's goals with key business objectives, and affected parties (for example, project managers) have the power and autonomy to make key decisions on the organization's behalf.

data.title: 5.19 Use Justice, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion (JEDI) practices
data.description: Implement JEDI practices to foster inclusive hiring practices within an organization, showing evidence of improvement over time.

criteria.title: JEDI practices
criteria.description: Document commitments to JEDI practices with clear policies on how marginalized or otherwise underserved communities are prioritized.

criteria.title: Accessibility policy
criteria.description: Establish a publicly displayed accessibility policy and demonstrate this via accessible digital products or services.

criteria.title: JEDI training
criteria.description: Provide JEDI-related training materials and schedule regular workshops related to how this topic manifests itself in digital products and services, covering topics such as algorithmic bias, digital divide, employment, mis- and disinformation.

criteria.title: JEDI improvements
criteria.description: Show measurable improvement over time across hiring, leadership, and operations.

criteria.title: JEDI legislation
criteria.description: Advocate for responsible legislation relating to JEDI practices, especially as they relate to digital products and services.

data.title: 5.20 Promote responsible data practices
data.description: Provide publicly accessible versions of documents required by law in a sustainable, easy-to-consume format, while also observing ethical data retention practices.

criteria.title: Data practices
criteria.description: Maintain a publicly accessible privacy policy, terms and conditions, and any other documents as required by law in the jurisdictions in which the product or service operates. Adhere to the most restrictive data protection regulations, especially when providing services outside the organization's country. Provide documents in accessible formats and use clear, user-friendly language to ensure comprehension by all users. Avoid unnecessary jargon, technical language, and legalese. Support emerging legislation and implement best practices related to data privacy, sustainability, and responsible data management.

criteria.title: Data ownership
criteria.description: Demonstrate measurable progress over time in regard to respecting data privacy and ownership. Specify how data disposal and a user's "right to be forgotten" or opt-out will be handled, along with ownership rights. Also, provide the ability to download or export data they have contributed into a non-proprietary format.

data.title: 5.21 Implement appropriate data management procedures
data.description: Allow users to manage, control, and delete their data upon request, while making outdated content searchable via a lightweight and simple archive.

criteria.title: Outdated content
criteria.description: Archive and delete outdated or otherwise expired product content and data via automated expiration dates and scheduled product audits. Publish the archiving schedule, ensuring a lightweight version of the old searchable content is maintained for those that may require it.

criteria.title: Data controllers
criteria.description: Allow users to control, manage, and delete their data, subscriptions, and accounts.

data.title: 5.22 Promote and implement responsible emerging technology practices
data.description: Implement policies, training, and auditing practices for new or emerging technologies to ensure sustainability upon implementation, while accounting for associated legal issues.

criteria.title: Emerging technologies
criteria.description: Establish public-facing policies for emerging technologies. Ensure all such technologies and their datasets are ethically sourced, screened, validated, and implemented in a non-discriminatory, responsible manner.

criteria.title: Disruptive technology
criteria.description: Show how workers are trained as new technologies and practices potentially disrupt an organizations business model.

criteria.title: Technology legislation
criteria.description: Support and comply with responsible legislation related to emerging technologies.

criteria.title: Environmental responsibilities
criteria.description: Audit and account for any environmental considerations that may derive from the use of emerging technologies wishing to be promoted or implemented. This should include third-party choices, the expense in terms of waste or emissions of using the technology to create a desired result, and consequences that may arise from its deployment.

criteria.title: Automated tooling
criteria.description: Ensure all automated tooling, scrapers, spiders, bots, artificial intelligence, and other forms of machine-assisted data gathering abides by requests to opt out at the host, server, or website level. Providers must declare themselves as non-human within the user-agent/HTTP header. Providers must also publish impact reports relating to their gathering activities.

criteria.title: Quantum resilience
criteria.description: Do not roll out post-quantum encryption for high-traffic services that do not need resilience against harvest now, decrypt later attacks, where attackers steal encrypted data, anticipating that future quantum computers will be powerful enough to break the encryption and make the data readable at a later date.

data.title: 5.23 Include responsible financial policies
data.description: Ensure that a project is suitably budgeted for and funded through sustainable and ethical sources.

criteria.title: Fuel divestment
criteria.description: Divest from fossil fuels and move banking, sponsorship, and other affiliations to more responsible partners.

criteria.title: Responsible finance
criteria.description: Engage in flexible financing and responsible budgeting to accommodate long-term care and maintenance.

data.title: 5.24 Include organizational philanthropy policies
data.description: Provide the opportunity to give back to the community through charitable or volunteer efforts via your organisation.

criteria.title: Philanthropy policy
criteria.description: Establish a clear corporate giving policy and create philanthropic partnerships with strategically aligned organizations.

criteria.title: Voluntary work
criteria.description: Engage in free or volunteer projects to help teams learn new tools and tactics, while also helping charities and non-profit organizations to build capacity.

data.title: 5.25 Plan for a digital product or service's care and end-of-life
data.description: Produce documentation to ensure that when a project is shut down, visitors are made aware of what will happen to their data.

criteria.title: End-of-life care
criteria.description: Provide clear, documented end-of-life guidelines that include data disposal, archiving, file deletion, and other relevant guidance.

data.title: 5.26 Include e-waste, right to repair, and recycling policies
data.description: Include policies and documentation explaining how sustainable e-waste, recycling, repairing, and refurbishment are handled.

criteria.title: E-waste policy
criteria.description: Establish specific policies around e-waste recycling and repair owned technology products whenever possible.

criteria.title: Recycling and repairing
criteria.description: Form relationships with local partners for e-waste recycling and repair.

criteria.title: Refurbishment strategy
criteria.description: Buy refurbished equipment whenever possible.

criteria.title: Right to repair
criteria.description: Allow consumers to repair the consumables they purchase to the best of their ability, offering replacement components if possible at cost, and provide clear instructions to help resolve faults that occur.

data.title: 5.27 Define performance and environmental budgets
data.description: Provide budgets, taking the people, planet, and performance into account alongside baselines, targets, evidence, and resources to help meet KPIs.

criteria.title: Environmental budget
criteria.description: Define and document clear sustainability budget criteria that covers impact from creation to consumption. Communicate this to affected parties.

criteria.title: Performance budget
criteria.description: Use a performance budget to set a target maximum size of your digital product or service to monitor and reduce impact of data transfer, file type size, and more.

criteria.title: Human budget
criteria.description: Define KPIs around engineering hours, development time, or sprints while keeping the health and well-being of your workers paramount. Sustainably optimize workflows to allow all tasks to be performed with care.

criteria.title: Measurable improvements
criteria.description: Establish a baseline and measurement criteria to track improvements over time. Improvement claims must be evidenced and verifiable.

criteria.title: Capacity and maintenance
criteria.description: Invest in resources to build capacity and maintain budgets over time.

data.title: 5.28 Use open source where possible
data.description: Produce a policy around open collaboration and contribution to creating and sustaining open source projects.

criteria.title: Open source policy
criteria.description: Establish a clear open source policy that outlines how open-source tools are used and any practices used to support open-source development.

criteria.title: Collaboration
criteria.description: Show a track record of collaboration and building communities around open-source principles.

criteria.title: Contribution
criteria.description: Contribute regularly in terms of code, human-time, and/or financially, to open-source community-based projects.

data.title: 5.29 Create a business continuity and disaster recovery plan
data.description: Create a plan of action with a system to recover from failure or alert users if or when a loss of service occurs.

criteria.title: Plan of action
criteria.description: Create, regularly review, and occasionally test a plan of action to determine readiness in case of an incident and establish procedures to quickly recover from any incident.

criteria.title: Audience awareness
criteria.description: Maintain regular and transparent communication with the audience regarding issues that may affect service delivery or user data.
